awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorter (FACS) for Multidisciplinary Research and Education at Fordham University
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Fordham University for the acquisition of a BD FACSMelody (BYG 6-Color Plate 4 way) fluorescence activated cell sorter (FACS) for a multiuser facility in the Chemistry Department at Fordham University. Acquisition of a state of the art instrument such as FACS will improve the research infrastructure and advance faculty research and training programs of students and postdocs across two campuses. It will enhance collaborative research opportunities between the Departments of Biological Sciences, Chemistry, Psychology and Natural Sciences as well as the broader community. It will also expose a growing cohort of undergraduate science majors to a powerful experimental tool in biochemistry. Students and faculty from minority institutions, including local community colleges and high schools, conducting research at Fordham will greatly benefit from learning such advanced techniques. In addition, it will help provide meaningful research and hands-on experience to undergraduate students through investigative laboratory experiments as part of the recently established Biochemistry minor and aid in expanding the Biochemistry program. It will enhance student’s ability to understand intricate cellular mechanisms, and provide them with the skills and scientific acumen to join the STEM workforce and participate in the society as scientifically literate individuals. Additionally, faculty plan on outreach activities such as creating podcasts for local senior citizen organizations so that the community’s vulnerable population can become more aware about cellular and physiological processes involved in diseases. Furthermore, workshops for local high school students will be held. These activities will promote recruitment, retention, and professional development of a diverse STEM workforce. 

The instrument will facilitate interdisciplinary research in key areas including tissue engineering, single-molecule biophysics, protein engineering, environmental science, neuropsychology and neuroscience. It will provide a cutting-edge multi-user instrument with high sensitivity for quantitative and qualitative investigation of a variety of cell populations in a high-throughput manner. FACS is a crucial tool for the separation of desired cell populations in high purity and analysis of single cells based on cell markers, size, and interactions. FACS is also the only purification technique to isolate and sort cells based on intracellular protein expression in a rapid and highly efficient manner. Thus, the FACS instrument will be employed in a variety of projects that include examining stem cell differentiation pathways at cell-biomaterial interfaces, investigating the molecular mechanisms of high-fidelity and error-prone DNA replication in bacteria, studying the environmental impacts of novel ionic liquids, examining cellular uptake of engineered peptides, studying the behavior of neuronal populations in transgenic zebrafish, examining the effects of stress hormones on leukocytes, as well as elucidating the mechanism of viral entry and trafficking to reduce HPV related infections. The research afforded by the instrument will allow Fordham faculty to make substantive contributions to a variety of important developing areas of biotechnology. As an institution in one of the most diverse cities in the country, the FACS instrument will provide an exceptional opportunity to impart high-quality research and teaching to a diverse student population at Fordham.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Description:

A BD FACSMelody flow cytometer with cell sorting capability supports the research conducted by faculty, students and postdocs from two campuses at Fordham University (Rose Hill and Lincoln Center). It has facilitated a wide array of research and teaching needs at Fordham. Not only has it benefited the scientific infrastructure at Fordham, and has propelled the establishment of the undergraduate Biochemistry major and a Master’s Program in Biotech, but it has also enabled in depth research in a broad range of fields. This instrument supports interdisciplinary research across the departments of Biological Sciences, Psychology, Chemistry and Biochemistry as well as Natural Sciences. It has enabled faculty and students (both undergraduate and graduate) to carry out investigations in tissue regeneration, study the cellular pathways involved in multicellular 3D spheroids and 3D bioprinted tumoroids. In addition, the influence of protein-protein interactions and their role in developing specific receptor-targeted peptide inhibitors; single molecule studies on bacterial DNA polymerases as well as the impact of diverse HPV16 proteins and their roles in triggering and promoting cancer are being studied. Additional research in the area of neurodegenerative diseases to mitigate the misfolding of proteins involved in those diseases are also being supported. Numerous students conducting undergraduate and graduate research are being trained and are able to contribute to research that has led to several publications. Furthermore, the FACS instrument facilitates course components for biochemistry labs, and Bionanotechnology and Introduction to Nanomedicine courses. Thus, the instrument advances a diverse range of research areas and addresses a number of fundamental questions in biotechnology, in addition to aiding training for a large number of students.

 Intellectual Merit:

The acquisition of the BD FACSMelody instrument significantly boosts the research and training capability of STEM faculty and students at Fordham University. The instrument has a BYG 6-Color Plate 4 way with cell sorter and includes two lasers, (488 nm; 561 nm), and six emission filters that aid in the detection of cell surface markers, fluorescent protein fusions and fluorophore conjugated antibodies. The instrument has also aided in the quantitative measurements of various intra and intercellular proteins, cytokines, analytes and growth factors. Several research projects continue to be furthered by the FACS instrument including exploring cancer stem cell differentiation pathways before and after treatment with specific peptide based drug molecules; analysis of intracellular protein aggregation and impact of natural product derived drug molecules; internalization of proteins in glial and neuronal cells; understanding the impact of human papillomavirus 16 (HPV 16) infection on cellular modifications in epithelial cells; investigation of cellular pathways such as apoptosis and necrosis in tumor cells; cellular differentiation in tissue engineered constructs. Furthermore, the instrument has allowed for the expansion of peptide cell permeability assays; testing antibiotic resistance of bacterial strains and examining the molecular mechanisms of high-fidelity and error-prone DNA replication in bacteria. Thus, the instrument has allowed Fordham faculty and students to carry out investigations in a multitude of biochemical processes at the molecular level. The innovative research contributions afforded by the FACS instrument allows Fordham faculty to address crucial questions and make important contributions to a number of developing areas in biotechnology.

Broader Impacts:

The FACS instrument has significantly enhanced the research infrastructure and support for research and teaching for undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs at Fordham University. Using this instrument, the experiments that faculty and students have been able to carry out thus far have led to several publications in peer reviewed scientific journals. Students and faculty have broadly disseminated the results obtained at conferences (local, regional, national and international conferences). In addition, undergraduate students from diverse STEM fields have been trained to use the instrument for a variety of research projects. Several current undergraduate students regularly use the instrument for their faculty-mentored research. Some of the students and faculty have received awards for their research and academic accomplishments. More data are currently being acquired that are yet to be published. Furthermore, the instrument helps in bringing cutting-edge techniques to educational efforts, particularly in biochemistry and biotechnology, to provide meaningful research and laboratory experience to students and propel their scientific careers to the next level. Many students are now pursuing Ph.D. or MD degrees at top universities in the country and have enormously benefited from the training. With the implementation of the Biochemistry major, a significantly large number of students are now expected to gain knowledge and expertise in the use of this instrument. Fordham's population of underrepresented and economically disadvantaged students has grown to ~50% over the past few years, and thus this instrument will help in building the scientific skills and upliftment of students from all backgrounds and will continue to benefit them, and provide them with the skills and to join the next generation STEM workforce.
